did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Craufurd D. Goodwin has served as a Professor of Economics and administrator at Duke University since 1962. Papers of Craufurd D. W. Goodwin, educator and administrator at Duke University, include correspondence, writings, and subject files relating to his roles as Professor of Economics, Director of International Studies, Vice Provost and Director of International Programs, Vice Provost for Research, and Dean of the Graduate School. Also includes materials from his work for the Ford Foundation.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.

For a period of twenty-five years from the origin of the material, permission in writing from the office of origin and the University Archivist is required for use. After twenty-five years, records that have been processed may be consulted with the permission of the University Archivist.

In accordance with the Family Education Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 as amended, Duke University permits students to inspect their education records and limits the disclosure of personally identifiable information from education records.
Records, such as search committee files or others pertaining to employment where individuals are identified, are closed for 70 years.
In off-site storage; 48 hours advance notice is required for use.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: Copyright for Official University records is held by Duke University; all other copyright is retained by the authors of items in these papers, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Craufurd D. W. Goodwin Papers, Duke University Archives, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Craufurd D. W. Goodwin papers were received by the University Archives from a variety of resources between 1985-1994. Accession (2009-0191) was added to the collection in September 2009. Accession (2009-0240) was added to the collection in November 2009.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Updated by Meghan Lyon, September 2009 and November 2009
Various accessions were merged into one collection, described in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Craufurd D. Goodwin has served as a Professor of Economics and administrator at Duke University since 1962. He was born on May 23, 1934 in Montreal, Canada. He earned a B. A. in Economics and Political Science from McGill University in 1955, and a Ph. D. in Economics from Duke University in 1958. He joined the faculty at Duke as a Professor of Economics in 1962. In addition to his teaching and research in economics, Goodwin has held a number of administrative positions at Duke University:

chronitem.event: Secretary of the University; Assistant to the Provost
Secretary of the University; Assistant Provost
Assistant Provost; Director of International Studies
Program Officer in Charge, European and International Affairs, The Ford Foundation
Vice Provost for Research and Dean of the Graduate School

bioghist.p: He has written and co-authored numerous books, most recently Economics and National Security: A History of Their Interaction (1991); Missing the Boat: The Failure to Internationalize American Higher Education (1991); Academic Mobility in a Changing World: Regional and Global Trends (ed. with A. Smith, U. Teichler and P. Blumenthal, 1996); Beyond Government: Extending the Public Policy Debate in Emerging Democracies (ed. with Michael Nacht, 1995); Talking to Themselves: The Search for Rights and Responsibilities of the Press and Mass Media in Four Latin American Nations (with Michael Nacht, 1995); The Academic's Handbook, 2nd Ed. (with Leigh DeNeef, 1995), and Art and the Market (1998).

He directs the Honors Program in the Department of Economics and is editor of the journal, History of Political Economy. He is currently the James B. Duke Professor of Economics and teaches introductory macroeconomics and microeconomics, as well as courses in the history of economic thought and policy.

scopecontent.p: Papers of Craufurd D. W. Goodwin, educator and administrator at Duke University, include correspondence, writings, and subject files relating to his roles as Professor of Economics, Director of International Studies, Vice Provost and Director of International Programs, Vice Provost for Research, and Dean of the Graduate School. Also included are records of the Board of Trustees Executive Committee, the Academic Council, the Provost Group, numerous economic and economic history professional societies, and several philanthropic foundations, including the Ford Foundation.

arrangement.p: Boxes 1-8: No accession info, material from 1960s. Boxes 9-10: Material received May 1, 1978. Boxes 11-12: A82-128. Boxes 13-14: A85-113. Boxes 15-21: A90-81. Boxes 22-25: A90-96. Boxes 26-29: A91-97. Box 30: A92-101. Boxes 31-32: A94-12. Box 33: A93-92 and A95-104. Box 34: A93-92. Boxes 35-36: A94-122.

scopecontent.p: Accession (2009-0191) (12375 items; 16.5 lin. ft.; dated 1960s-2000) consists largely of Ford Foundation materials on a variety of subjects, as well as additional Duke administrative and Economics Department files, and research files collected by Goodwin on Australian and international economics. The Ford Foundation files include correspondence, reports, grant and policy papers, and other materials relating to human rights, international relations, education, and public policy, among other subjects.

arrangement.p: This addition was accessioned according to Rubenstein Library procedures and then added to the existing University Archives collection. It is unprocessed; the container list below reflects the original condition of the materials at the time of their arrival at the Library.

did.unittitle: Truman administration energy policy research notes

scopecontent.p: Includes, but is not limited to, materials (information papers, discussion papers, reports, etc.) on human rights; international migration and refugees; United States foreign policy; the world economy; and arts and culture.

scopecontent.p: Accession (2009-0240) (2250 items; 3.0 lin. ft.; dated 1960s-2000) includes a variety of materials relating to the Ford Foundation and Duke's Economics Department, as well as personal correspondence, History of Political Economy journal materials, research with fellow economist Michael Nacht, and correspondence about the Cambridge University Press.

arrangement.p: This addition was accessioned according to Rubenstein Library procedures and then added to the existing University Archives collection. It is unprocessed; the container list below reflects the original condition of the materials at the time of their arrival at the Library.
